title: Twitter board will hire Jack Dorsey as CEO - Sacca
text:
Investor Chris Sacca spoke at a #talkingtechLIVE event at JibJab studios. (Photo: Jefferson Graham)
6 CONNECT 59 TWEET LINKEDIN COMMENT EMAIL MORE LOS ANGELES - Outspoken Twitter shareholder Chris Sacca has no doubt he will win his war with the Twitter board of directors.
“I will get what I want,” he said Wednesday night, at a #talkingtechLIVE podcast event here.
The Twitter board has been mulling hiring a new CEO for the micro-blogging service since June, when former CEO Dick Costolo resigned. The board “is stuck, jammed up with members who don’t own a lot of stock, don’t use the product and are in the way,” he said.
They will turn around soon, he believes, and give the post to Twitter co-founder Jack Dorsey, who is currently serving as interim CEO, while also running his company Square.
Sacca, who has been pegged by Forbes as worth more than $1 billion for his investments in such tech companies as Uber, Instagram, Kickstarter and others, believes Dorsey can run Twitter and his other company Square at the same time.
"Basically, at all costs, we need to keep the founders involved."
Sacca will be a “guest shark,” on the ABC investment show Shark Tank this season. He says firms always do best with founders at the helm.
“There’s no reason for this,” he says of the board’s actions. “It’s negligent at this point. The board has opened itself up to liability.”
Tech investor Chris Sacca (Photo: Jefferson Graham)
He addressed the diversity issue that’s haunted Silicon Valley, saying it stems from boards who are mostly male and mostly white. When they get more diverse, staffs will as well, he says.
"The representation of women and people of color on #tech boards is appalling." - @sacca #talkingtechLIVE
— Bryan Copley (@rybanc) September 24, 2015 Inspired to see @sacca focus on #diversity of voices and perspectives as critical and profit generating for #startups #talkingtechlive
— Vishal Sharma (@vishne0) September 24, 2015 Sacca, who runs his investment firm Lowercase Capital from Manhattan Beach, a suburb of Los Angeles, was one of the earliest investors in Uber, the ride app service that he believes is potentially worth more than Facebook.
The audience listens--and Periscopes, at #talkingtechLIVE event (Photo: Jefferson Graham)
“How much money did you spend on Facebook this month?” he asked, rhetorically.
Facebook is currently worth $264 billion, and for Uber,
“I’m not selling it, I’m buying it. It will be a worth a lot more than it is today, and if you have any, I’ll buy it from you.”
He sees Uber becoming a major factor in package and restaurant take-out delivery, beyond just rides.
@sacca tells @JeffersonGraham " @Uber has more data about things being moved around the world than @FedEx does." Incredible. #TalkingTechLIVE
— Gabriela Dow (@GabrielaDow) September 24, 2015 "As an investor, I’m a believer. You have to believe this thing can be big, you’ll have an opportunity to get rich, and you can impact the outcome, otherwise you may as well be playing the public market. I want to have an impact.”
Chris Sacca speaks at #talkingtechLIVE event in Los Angeles (Photo: Jefferson Graham)
